TITLE: These legislative proposals may affect your wallet. What to watch for this fall
SUMMARY: As the Senate wraps up before recess, some bills and proposals may resurface this fall or next year. Experts decipher which ones may make it through Congress.

TITLE: Schools weigh vaccine and mask mandates as students prepare to return
SUMMARY: Most schools plan to be fully in person in the fall, although the country remains divided on masking and vaccination requirements.

TITLE: Op-ed: Sometimes it's just worth paying someone to handle various tasks and chores
SUMMARY: If you can afford to hire someone to perform some services for you, you can see benefits ranging from better health to more free time.

TITLE: Biden extends payment pause for student loan borrowers through January
SUMMARY: The 42 million Americans with student debt will not have to resume their payments until February, according to an announcement Friday by the White House.

TITLE: The Covid-19 pandemic prompted new worries about Social Security. Here's how the outlook has shifted with the recovery
SUMMARY: The onset of the Covid-19 pandemic prompted fears that Social Security would suffer financially. Here's how that outlook has changed.

TITLE: Lawmakers want to make it easier to have guaranteed income in retirement
SUMMARY: Under pending bipartisan retirement legislation in the House and Senate, the rules applying to qualified longevity annuity contracts, or QLACs, would be eased.

TITLE: Renters are behind $3,700 in rent, on average. This map shows a state breakout
SUMMARY: How much renters were set back by the pandemic varies sharply between states and counties.

TITLE: Student loan forgiveness scams are on the rise. How to avoid falling victim
SUMMARY: Scams offering student loan forgiveness have increased amid confusion around pandemic programs and calls to erase the debt. Here's what to know.

TITLE: Pandemic-era relief is drying up. But families still have options
SUMMARY: Many of the relief programs created during the pandemic to help struggling families are winding down. Here's what you need to know.

TITLE: Russian group releases stolen credit cards on dark web. Here's how to protect your credit from criminals
SUMMARY: An estimated 1 million stolen credit cards were posted on the dark web, and it may be time you take steps to prevent fraudsters from using your personal data.

TITLE: Consider these hidden taxes before piling into muni bonds
SUMMARY: Investors piling into municipal bonds may get hit with higher Social Security taxes and Medicare premiums. Here’s what retirees need to know.

TITLE: Retired and returning to work: How the extra income could collide with other financial considerations
SUMMARY: Although extra income from a job can let you leave more in your retirement account to grow, it may negatively affect other aspects of your financial life.

TITLE: Here's who would benefit from proposed changes to 401(k) 'catch-up' contributions
SUMMARY: Under a provision included in both Senate and House retirement bills, so-called "catch-up contributions" would be expanded.

TITLE: What you need to know if you're in danger of being evicted
SUMMARY: A new eviction moratorium from the CDC has confused some renters. Here's what to know if you're worried about losing your housing.

TITLE: Many Americans couldn't afford a $400 expense prior to Covid-19. How stimulus checks changed that
SUMMARY: Even Americans without work were able to shore up their savings thanks to stimulus checks. But whether those balances will stay remains to be seen.

TITLE: 26 states ended federal unemployment benefits early. Data suggests it’s not getting people back to work
SUMMARY: Data from payroll firms Homebase and UKG, similar to other recent studies, indicate state policies haven't pushed people back to work yet.

TITLE: Collecting unemployment? Most states re-impose a 'look for work' requirement
SUMMARY: Laid-off workers didn't have to look for work to collect unemployment benefits early in the Covid pandemic. Most states have re-imposed the requirement.

TITLE: Are you protected under the new eviction ban? Here's what you need to know
SUMMARY: After the national eviction ban expired on July 31, the CDC issued a new protection for renters. This time, the rules are a little more complicated.

TITLE: More workers plan to quit as better job opportunities open up
SUMMARY: In what's being called the "Great Resignation," a record number of job openings has given workers the upper hand.

TITLE: These retirees are more likely to be ‘comfortable’ or ‘affluent,’ study finds
SUMMARY: These factors are most common among those who are "comfortable" or "affluent" in retirement, according to a study. Here are the key takeaways.

TITLE: Op-ed: Real estate investment trusts may provide inflation protection for investors
SUMMARY: Real estate investment trusts are rebounding due to the recession recovery and a concern

TITLE: CDC issues new eviction ban effective through Oct. 3
SUMMARY: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention issued a new eviction ban across most of the country until October as the delta variant surges.

TITLE: 'Tax hesitancy' could hold parents back from signing up for the child tax credit. Why those fears are unfounded
SUMMARY: Monthly child tax credit payments have started. Some low-income parents are hesitant to file with the IRS. That leaves a lot of money on the table.

TITLE: Here's how much 2021 winners of Mega Millions and Powerball have forked over in taxes
SUMMARY: Between the Powerball and Mega Millions jackpots that have been claimed so far this year, winners have paid more than $500 million in federal taxes.

TITLE: Infrastructure bill pulls $31 billion from Covid disaster loan program
SUMMARY: The Senate's $1 trillion legislation would permanently claw back funds Congress offered to businesses hard-hit by the Covid pandemic.

TITLE: Senate infrastructure bill cracks down on crypto tax reporting. How it may affect investors
SUMMARY: The Senate’s $1 trillion bipartisan infrastructure bill calls for a crackdown on cryptocurrency tax reporting. Here's how it may affect investors and brokers.

TITLE: Investing some savings is one of the best ways to grow your wealth
SUMMARY: Investors in their 20s are holding nearly as much cash as retirees, according to Personal Capital. There are better ways to grow that money.

TITLE: Black women make nearly $1 million less than white men during their careers
SUMMARY: Black women are paid an average 63 cents for each dollar paid to non-Hispanic white men. In effect, they must work 579 days to make what white men earn in 365.

TITLE: Tuition insurance may help cover costs if a student withdraws from college
SUMMARY: The possibility of more campus closures has sparked renewed interest in college refund policies and tuition insurance.

TITLE: Here’s where return-to-office plans stand now
SUMMARY: A recent surge in Covid cases due to the delta variant have caused some employers to delay their return-to-office plans.
